\#\#\# User: A classic data structure for describing the topology of a polygon layer is the polygon\-arc table and left\-right polygon table as described [in the ArcGIS documentation](https://desktop.arcgis.com/en/arcmap/latest/manage-data/coverages/coverage-topology.htm) and the following illustration from the same link:

[![polygon arc table](https://i.stack.imgur.com/0cVWF.gif)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/0cVWF.gif)

Basically, for each polygon, its list of arcs is stored (polygon\-arc table); and for each arc, the two incident polygons on its left and on its right are stored (left\-right polygon table).

My questions are:

*Given a input polygon table, does PostGIS (as of 3\.x) have functions to compute the polygon\-arc table and left\-right polygon table as two relational tables (plus maybe a third table for arc geometry)?*

*If not, how to write SQL statements/functions to compute the two tables?*

Here I am assuming that the polygon layer is digitized in a topologically consistent manner (e.g. with snapping options in modern GISes).

Note: I have read about the PostGIS topology extension. But it seems to be different. It seems to be more complex than the polygon\-arc table in that 1\) it involves multiple tables and [requires joining these tables](https://gis.stackexchange.com/questions/60383/), 2\) that the examples I've seen are based on building topology for roads, not spatial tessellation, and 3\) I am not sure whether PostGIS topology avoids the duplicate storage of common boundaries between polygons as the polygon\-arc table does.

I also looked at other open source solutions such as ogr/gdal, and it does not seem to support writing coverage files.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The topology extension of PostGIS has facilities to create topologies and to add linestrings and polygons to the topology. When created, topology is created as a set of tables in a new schema: node, edge\_data, face, and relation. Then you can start to add linestrings and polygons to the topology (using, for example,`TopoGeo_AddLineString()` and `TopoGeo_AddPolygon()`). These functions do the work of creating nodes, edges and faces in the topology as feature geometries are added and the intersections are detected.

PostGIS topology supports topogeometries. These are geometries composed out of topology primitives (edges, nodes, faces) or other topogeometries. You can think, in the simplest case, of a topogeometry as the list of identifiers of shareable topology elements that constitute that feature. For example, a road centerline topogeometry would be a list of edges that might also be used as parts of faces forming neighbourhoods in a different table defining area topogeometries.

[*PostGIS in Action, 3rd Edition*](https://www.manning.com/books/postgis-in-action-third-edition), Chapter 13, by Leo S. Hsu and Regina O. Obe, provides a good introductory overview of PostGIS topology, first using a simplified topology of Colorado divided by interstate highways and then using the neighbourhoods of Victoria, B.C. to demonstrate the ideas. (I'm not affiliated with the authors or the publisher \- I have used it in a course)

QGIS provides a handy viewer for PostGIS topology in its DB Manager interface (Schema \-\> TopoViewer).

Update \- example
=================

All of the work below was done using psql, except for the use of QGIS to create the topology image (TopoViewer).

Create a pair of overlapping geometries.
----------------------------------------

```
-- might need to disconnect / reconnect for postgis and topology paths to be picked up properly
-- after creating these extensions and updating the search_path
CREATE SCHEMA postgis;
CREATE EXTENSION postgis SCHEMA postgis;
ALTER DATABASE set search_path=contrib,public,postgis,topology;
CREATE EXTENSION postgis_topology;

-- create table to hold overlapping polygons and then insert them
CREATE TABLE poly (
  id serial PRIMARY KEY,
  geom Geometry(POLYGON, 32618)
);

INSERT INTO poly (geom) VALUES
                        (ST_Polygon('LINESTRING(75 29, 77 29, 77 31, 75 31, 75 29)'::geometry, 32618)),
                        (ST_Polygon('LINESTRING(76 30, 78 30, 78 32, 76 32, 76 30)'::geometry, 32618));

```

Now create a new topology and insert the geometries.
----------------------------------------------------

Results in a new schema containing the required tables edge\_data, face, node and relation.

```
-- create a topology and push geomtries from poly into it
SELECT CreateTopology('polytopo', 32618);

SELECT 
  id, 
  TopoGeo_AddPolygon('polytopo', geom) As face_id
  FROM (
    SELECT id, geom 
      FROM poly
  ) As f;

```

Inserting these polygons into the topology will result in updates to the topology tables. Using the QGIS TopoViewer and displaying the directed edges shows the following structure. There are three marked faces (1, 2 and 3\) although there is actually a fourth \- the universal face (0\) not shown. Edges 1 through 6 are labelled and the grey circles are the topology nodes.

[![View of topology created by inserting polygons](https://i.stack.imgur.com/1xXjv.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/1xXjv.png)

List edges for faces.
---------------------

PostGIS topology includes constructor functions and topology accessors. To list the edge IDs for a specific face, use [`ST_GetFaceEdges()`](https://postgis.net/docs/ST_GetFaceEdges.html). This dumps all edges for a given face (quoting from the documentation):

> Enumeration of each ring edges start from the edge with smallest
> identifier. Order of edges follows a left\-hand\-rule (bound face is on
> the left of each directed edge).

The following query lists all edges for all faces. Here each edge is its own row. I'll aggregate the edges for each list into an ordered array below.

```
-- show ordered edges for faces
WITH faces AS (
  SELECT face_id FROM polytopo.face
)
SELECT face_id,
       (ST_GetFaceEdges('polytopo', face_id)).*
  FROM faces
 ORDER BY face_id, sequence;

```

The result of the above is shown below. Negative edge IDs indicate that the ordered traversal would go against the direction of the edge to keep the bounded area to the left of the edge. For example, the traversal of the universal face (0\) runs against the edge direction for all arcs because the face is outside the drawn faces and therefore left of the outer arcs only when traversing them in reverse.

```
 face_id | sequence | edge 
---------+----------+------
       0 |        1 |   -1
       0 |        2 |   -2
       0 |        3 |   -6
       1 |        1 |    1
       1 |        2 |   -5
       1 |        3 |   -3
       1 |        4 |    2
       2 |        1 |    3
       2 |        2 |    5
       2 |        3 |    4
       3 |        1 |   -4
       3 |        2 |    6
(12 rows)

```

List edges for each face as an ordered array (single row)
---------------------------------------------------------

I am not sure if this is more useful than the query above. Depends what you are trying to do. But this is more similar to the polygon\-arc table in the original question so I show it.

```
-- show ordered edges for faces, grouped into ordered arrays
WITH faces AS (
  SELECT face_id FROM polytopo.face
), oedges AS (
  SELECT face_id,
         (ST_GetFaceEdges('polytopo', face_id)).*
    FROM faces
)
SELECT face_id, array_agg(edge) AS edge_ids
  FROM oedges
 GROUP BY face_id
 ORDER BY face_id;

```

The result form the above query is shown below. The logic of the ordered lists is the same as for the previous query. I've removed the sequence number from the display while creating an ordered array of edge IDs.

```
 face_id |  edge_ids   
---------+-------------
       0 | {-1,-2,-6}
       1 | {1,-5,-3,2}
       2 | {3,5,4}
       3 | {-4,6}
(4 rows)

```

Summary
=======

Within the topology, only the edge\_data table contains the boundary geometries. The face table stores only face IDs and minimum bounding boxes. Those face IDs are used in the edge table to relate each edge to the faces bounded by that edge and to store information about sequencing of edges around faces (see the table definition for details). The node table stores point geometries that are, technically, a duplication of the arc endpoint vertices but a reasonable trade\-off for efficiency. The relation table relates topology elements, especially edges, to application feature geometries (topogeometries, mentioned earlier) that can be composed from topology elements at the lowest layer or from other topogeometries to create layered relationships within the topology (e.g., "blocks" could be composed from "parcels" that are, in turn, topology faces bounded by topology edges). In the example above, no topogeometries have been created so the relation table is still empty.

As opposed to the creation of face edge lists, shown in the examples above, face boundary geometry can be (re)created using [`ST_GetFaceGeometry()`](https://postgis.net/docs/ST_GetFaceGeometry.html).

40.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In PostGIS topology, which of the following statements is true regarding the storage and representation of polygons?

A) The face table stores complete polygon geometries for each face.
B) The edge_data table contains boundary geometries, while the face table only stores face IDs and bounding boxes.
C) Topogeometries are always composed of individual nodes and cannot be built from other topogeometries.
D) The relation table directly stores the geometry of features composed from topology elements.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
A) Incorrect. The face table does not store complete polygon geometries. It only stores face IDs and minimum bounding boxes.
B) Correct. As stated in the summary, "Within the topology, only the edge_data table contains the boundary geometries. The face table stores only face IDs and minimum bounding boxes."
C) Incorrect. Topogeometries can be composed of topology primitives (edges, nodes, faces) or other topogeometries, allowing for layered relationships.
D) Incorrect. The relation table does not store geometries directly. It relates topology elements to application feature geometries (topogeometries) but does not store the actual geometry.

\#\#\# User: What's the difference between "case by case" and "case to case"?

I often hear the former from my Japanese students. When I asked them where they got the phrase, they always say they learned it from their high school grammar lessons.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This is probably due to difficulty with prepositions, for which it is harder to learn by rules than by experience! The preposition "by" is used in "X by X" where "X" is a noun to adverbially specify that the main verb is performed to each "X" in the context one at a time. Some examples are:

> one by one (one at a time)
> 
> 
> line by line (one line at a time)
> 
> 
> case by case (one case at a time)
> 
> 
> day by day (one day at a time)

In contrast, the adverbial phrase "X to X" specifies that the main verb is performed to the "X"s in the context from one to another. It need not imply that all "X"s are involved, but simply conveys the process of going from one to another, usually repeatedly.

> \[from] house to house (repeatedly out from a house into another)
> 
> 
> \[from] time to time (occasionally)
> 
> 
> \[from] cover to cover (start of a book to the end)

Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Which of the following phrases best describes a situation where a company evaluates employee performance individually, considering each employee's unique circumstances and contributions?

A) Case to case
B) Case by case
C) Case for case
D) Case after case

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
The correct answer is B) "Case by case." This phrase indicates that each case (in this context, each employee's performance) is evaluated individually, one at a time. 

"Case by case" follows the pattern explained in the documentation where "X by X" is used to specify that something is done to each item in a set individually. This is similar to other examples given like "one by one" or "day by day."

A) "Case to case" is incorrect because it implies movement from one case to another, rather than individual consideration. As explained in the documentation, "X to X" phrases typically indicate movement or progression between items, not individual examination.

C) "Case for case" is not a standard English phrase and doesn't convey the intended meaning of individual evaluation.

D) "Case after case" suggests a sequential examination but doesn't emphasize the individual nature of each evaluation as strongly as "case by case."

This question tests understanding of idiomatic expressions and their subtle differences in meaning, making it challenging for language learners.

Question: In the given LaTeX code for creating an algorithm with parallel execution, what combination of commands is used to add the curly brace and "in parallel" text to indicate parallel execution?

A) \smash and \rule
B) \hspace and \raisebox
C) \left and \right
D) All of the above

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D - All of the above. The code uses a combination of several LaTeX commands to achieve the desired effect:

1. \smash is used to make the construction have zero height, allowing it to overlap with other lines.
2. \hspace is used to position the brace horizontally.
3. \raisebox is used to adjust the vertical position of the brace.
4. \left and \right are used to create the curly brace.
5. \rule is used to control the height of the brace.

These commands work together to create the curly brace and "in parallel" text that spans multiple lines of the algorithm, indicating parallel execution. The exact combination and parameters of these commands can be adjusted to fine-tune the appearance and positioning of the brace.

Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Consider the equation $2^n - 1 = \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} 2^k$. Which of the following statements is true?

A) This equation is incorrect because it's missing a factor of 2 on the right-hand side.

B) This equation can be proved using induction, starting with the base case n=1.

C) The left-hand side of this equation represents the sum of all powers of 2 from 2^0 to 2^(n-1).

D) This equation can be proved by expanding $2^n$ as $(2^{n-1} + 2^{n-1})$ and continuing this process recursively.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation:
A) is incorrect because the equation is actually correct as stated.
B) is incorrect because while induction could be used, the base case would be n=0, not n=1.
C) is incorrect because the left-hand side $2^n - 1$ doesn't directly represent a sum; it's the right-hand side that represents the sum of powers of 2.
D) is correct. As shown in the documentation, one can prove this equation by repeatedly expanding powers of 2, starting with $2^n = 2^{n-1} + 2^{n-1}$ and continuing this process until reaching $2^0 = 1$. This method demonstrates why the sum of powers of 2 from $2^0$ to $2^{n-1}$ equals $2^n - 1$.

\#\#\# User: Related to this: [Exchange Online RBAC \- How to limit the read scope of a management role?](https://serverfault.com/questions/1106337/exchange-online-rbac-how-to-limit-the-read-scope-of-a-management-role).

We need to allow some administrators to manage only a subset of all mailboxes in Exchange Online; we achieved this using a management scope.

Everything works as expected if the limited administrators access the Exchange Admin Center (<https://admin.exchange.microsoft.com>); however, they are unable to access the main Microsoft 365 Admin Center (<https://admin.microsoft.com>). It looks like in order to access that you have to be granted one of the standard Microsoft 365 admin roles: having only an Exchange\-specific custom role will not help you.

How can we allow those limited administrators to access the Microsoft 365 Admin Center (without granting them additional rights, of course)?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You can assign the global reader role to users who need to be limited.

*Assign the global reader role to users who need to view admin features and settings in admin centers that the global admin can view. The global reader admin can't edit any settings.*

Refer to this [document](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/add-users/about-admin-roles?view=o365-worldwide#:%7E:text=In%20the%20Microsoft%20365%20admin%20center%2C%20you%20can%20go%20to%20Role%20assignments%2C%20and%20then%20select%20any%20role%20to%20open%20its%20detail%20pane.%20Select%20the%20Permissions%20tab%20to%20view%20the%20detailed%20list%20of%20what%20admins%20assigned%20that%20role%20have%20permissions%20to%20do.%20Select%20the%20Assigned%20or%20Assigned%20admins%20tab%20to%20add%20users%20to%20roles.) for your reference.

45.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An organization wants to allow certain administrators to manage a subset of mailboxes in Exchange Online while also granting them access to the Microsoft 365 Admin Center without providing additional rights. Which of the following approaches would best achieve this goal?

A) Assign the administrators a custom Exchange-specific role with a management scope
B) Grant the administrators one of the standard Microsoft 365 admin roles
C) Assign the administrators the Global Reader role
D) Provide the administrators with direct access to https://admin.microsoft.com

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A) While assigning a custom Exchange-specific role with a management scope would allow administrators to manage a subset of mailboxes in Exchange Online, it would not grant them access to the Microsoft 365 Admin Center.

B) Granting standard Microsoft 365 admin roles would likely provide more permissions than necessary, contradicting the requirement of not granting additional rights.

C) This is the correct approach. The Global Reader role allows users to view admin features and settings in admin centers that the global admin can view, without the ability to edit any settings. This meets the requirement of providing access to the Microsoft 365 Admin Center without granting additional rights.

D) Simply providing direct access to the admin portal URL would not work without the appropriate permissions, and does not address the need for limited administration capabilities.

\#\#\# User: I asked a question about interpolating polynomials ([fit numpy polynomials to noisy data](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49201515/fit-numpy-polynomials-to-noisy-data)) and initially was given really mean\-spirited and bad advice. Two particular users gave me a really hard time for asking the question and insisted that my problem was caused by not understanding machine precision. One of those two deleted his answer when the correct answer was posted. These two gave really bad advice, and if I didn't know better, I might have been discouraged and deleted the question. Is there any action I can take against these users besides flagging as breaking the "be nice" policy?

![Screenshot of comments](https://i.stack.imgur.com/4pPQh.png)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: No, you shouldn't flag because an answer you feel that it's incorrect. If an answer is wrong and helpful, it's wrong and unhelpful. In that case, downvote it. If others find that it's unhelpful as well, they'll downvote it and cause the answerer to either lose rep, or cause them to outright delete the answer. The former is a just "punishment" for bad answers, and upholds the quality requirements of the site, and the later prevents the bad answer from wasting anyone else's time.

Or, think of it this way: if you flag an answer as factually incorrect, the responding moderator must have domain knowledge to decide what action to take. Voting offloads that work onto the community, where there's a much higher chance of getting someone with domain knowledge to judge the answer. Apparently there's actually a default denial reason for moderators that flags should not be used to report incorrect answers (thanks @Catija for pointing this out). 

If you're mad because someone said something snippy to you and proved to be unhelpful later, I'd just cut your losses and move on. If you're on a popular tag, I'd just hope that someone else with more knowledge on the topic sees the question and can give you a better answer later.

---

As for the comment, the "oh boy" bit is a little snooty sounding, but I don't know if that really violates the "be nice" policy. The tone is unfortunate, but I wouldn't go as far as to suggest moderator intervention. 

I'll add though because I saw Anne's comment: if someone's commenting just to comment and abusing the purpose of comments (requesting clarification of the question), for the sake of cleaning up the site, you can flag it to have them cleaned. In this case though, it does appear that they are attempting to flesh out a solution by trying to clarify what the problem may be.

\#\#\# User: despite both zetas $ \\zeta (s,X) $ and $ \\zeta (s)$ have the same functional equation, the same Euler prodcut and the same Riemann\-Weil formula 

why one of them is 'easy' and can be solved but the other is so hard?? the zeta one $ \\zeta (s)$

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: One obvious difference, from a purely analytic point of view, is that $\\zeta(s,X)$ is a function of $p^{\-s}$, i.e. it is periodic by an imaginary number. This makes $\\zeta(s,X)$ much simpler, e.g. the set of roots is also periodic, so there are only finitely many roots to consider. In fact the functional equation forces that $\\zeta(s,X)$ is essentially a reciprocal polynomial in $p^{\-s}$, which further simplifies the analysis. From a structural point of view, $\\zeta(s,X)$ encodes a geometric object which comes with a natural topology, a Galois action, schemes and (co)homology groups derived from them; while a number field is not an algebraic variety, it has archimedean valuations, residue fields of every characteristic etc. Of course it might be the case that RH is not so hard, we just don't know.

47.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Which of the following statements best explains why the Riemann zeta function ζ(s) is considered more difficult to analyze than the Hurwitz zeta function ζ(s,X)?

A) The Riemann zeta function lacks a functional equation, while the Hurwitz zeta function has one.

B) The Hurwitz zeta function is periodic with respect to an imaginary number, leading to simpler root analysis.

C) The Riemann zeta function does not have an Euler product representation.

D) The Hurwitz zeta function encodes a geometric object with a natural topology, while the Riemann zeta function does not.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. The key difference highlighted in the documentation is that the Hurwitz zeta function ζ(s,X) is periodic with respect to an imaginary number (specifically, it's a function of p^(-s)). This periodicity simplifies its analysis in several ways:

1. It results in a periodic set of roots, meaning there are only finitely many roots to consider.
2. The functional equation forces ζ(s,X) to essentially be a reciprocal polynomial in p^(-s), further simplifying its analysis.

Option A is incorrect because both functions have functional equations. Option C is wrong because both functions have Euler product representations. Option D, while mentioning a true aspect of ζ(s,X), is not the primary reason for its relative simplicity compared to ζ(s).

The Riemann zeta function ζ(s), in contrast, lacks this periodicity and simple polynomial structure, making its analysis much more complex. This is why the Riemann Hypothesis, which concerns the zeros of ζ(s), remains one of the most challenging unsolved problems in mathematics.

\#\#\# User: I understand Stack Exchange follows the Q\&A format. But how do I share great ideas that I stumble upon and think it maybe useful to others as well?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Formulate it as a question and an answer. [Self\-answering questions is allowed and encouraged](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/132886/what-is-this-answer-your-own-question-jazz). 

There is a big "but" here though: Both the question and answer have to be good. That is, you can't get away with a lousy question just because you add an in\-depth answer. Nor will a poor answer suffice if your question is great. All the usual rules for both questions and answers will still apply. In fact, the community (whether fair or not) tends to take a more firm stance on self\-answered questions. 

If you feel that you can't formulate your "tips" in such a way that it can stand up to scrutiny, Stack Exchange will not be the platform for it. In such a case you're indeed better off posting it on your blog or site.

\#\#\# User: Is there anyway to delete and/or forget a technique that someone learns? From what I can tell you can only learn so many techniques.. how do you delete them?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You are misunderstanding the information available to you. You can't unlearn techs and you wouldn't want to.

Each player can learn all techs. Here's how that works:

* Each player starts with a number of techs that they can learn.
* One of those techs is the first key tech that will unlock the ability to
learn the next group of techs.
* The next group which includes the second key tech for unlocking
the following group after that.
* This group includes the third and final key tech for unlocking the ability to learn all remaining techs.
* The key techs and distribution of techs are different for each player.
* Learn techs by using techcopy (Low\-level players cannot learn techs from high\-level players) or as tournament rewards (you can't learn abilities from tiers you haven't unlocked for that character).

Here's an example (I've noted the key techs in bold \- once you learn those, you gain access to the next level):

> Wakka
> -----
> 
> 
> * ***Starting Techs***: Venom Shot
> * ***Normal Techs***: Anti\-Drain, Brawler, Elite Defence, Hi\-Risk, Nap Pass, Nap Shot, Nap Tackle, Sphere Shot, Spin Ball, Venom Pass, Venom Shot, Venom Shot 2, Venom Tackle, Volley Shot, Wither Pass, **Wither Shot**
> * ***Level 1 Techs***: Anti\-Venom, **Drain Tackle**, Drain Tackle 2, Golden Arm, Grip Gloves, Nap Pass 2, Nap Shot 2, Pile Wither, Regen, Venom Pass 2, Venom Pass 3, Volley Shot 2, Wither Pass 2, Wither Pass 3, Wither Shot 2, Wither Tackle, Wither Tackle 2
> * ***Level 2 Techs***: Anti\-Drain 2, Anti\-Nap, Anti\-Wither, Auroch's Spirit, Drain Tackle 3, Good Morning!, Invisible Shot, Nap Tackle 2, Pile Venom, Super Goalie, **Tackle Slip**, Tackle Slip 2, Venom Shot 3, Venom Tackle 3, Volley Shot 3
> * ***Level 3 Techs***: Anti\-Nap 2, Anti\-Venom 2, Anti\-Wither 2, Gamble, Nap Pass 3, Nap Shot 3, Nap Tackle 3, Venom Tackle 2, Wither Shot 3, Wither Tackle 3

Each player can only equip a number of techs according to their level. Once you reach level 3, you can equip one tech and, as you level, you will be able to equip more up to the maximum of 5\.

All of this information is available in the many guides on the subject, but I find [AlaskaFox's Blitzball Guide](http://www.gamefaqs.com/ps2/197344-final-fantasy-x/faqs/19103) the most useful as it has complete player listings with each player's key techs and which techs are in which tier.

\#\#\# User: So in the canonical ensemble we have a system inside of a heat reservoir, which can exchange energy with the system. This means the energy of the system is not necessarily a constant value but determined effectively by the local energy distribution of the reservoir.

What I'm essentially asking is if we took two "snapshots" of the canonical ensemble at two different times and looked at the energy of the system would we have some probability of finding the system to be at some energies E1 and E2 where they differ only because the system happens to be in a "colder" or "hotter" region of the reservoir due to the random distribution of energy throughout the reservoir?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The line element in polar coordinates is $\\vec{ds}\=dr\\hat{r}\+rd\\theta\\hat{\\theta}$. 

Divide by dt, you get $\\frac{\\vec{ds}}{dt}\=\\frac{dr}{dt}\\hat{r}\+r\\frac{d\\theta}{dt}\\hat{\\theta}$

We are given that $\\frac{dr}{dt}\=12m/s$ and $\\frac{d\\theta}{dt}\=2$rad/s. We multiply by 8 m to get $r\\frac{d\\theta}{dt}\=16$m/s.

The instantaneous velocity is the vector sum of the two. The magnitude of the instantaneous velocity is the square root of the sum of the square of the components, 20 m/s.

52.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A particle is moving in polar coordinates with radial velocity dr/dt = 12 m/s and angular velocity dθ/dt = 2 rad/s at a distance of 8 m from the origin. What is the magnitude of the particle's velocity vector, and what is the angle between the velocity vector and the radial direction?

A) Magnitude: 20 m/s, Angle: 45°
B) Magnitude: 20 m/s, Angle: 53.1°
C) Magnitude: 28 m/s, Angle: 36.9°
D) Magnitude: 24 m/s, Angle: 60°

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
The magnitude of the velocity vector is correctly calculated as 20 m/s in the given information. For the angle, we need to use the arctangent function:

angle = arctan(rθ̇ / ṙ) = arctan(16 / 12) ≈ 53.1°

Option A is incorrect because while the magnitude is correct, the angle is not 45°.
Option C is incorrect in both magnitude and angle.
Option D is incorrect in both magnitude and angle.
Option B correctly gives both the magnitude (20 m/s) and the angle (53.1°) between the velocity vector and the radial direction.

\#\#\# User: I would like to verify the integrity of my Exchange 2010 database backups and could use some guidance.

We have an Microsoft Small Business Server 2011 server that we backup but I don't know if the backups are any good yet. Since I don't have the hardware beefy enough to install SBS again and practice a restore, I thought maybe I could simply export a backed up copy of the Exchange database to a USB drive and run some tool on it to verify that it passes integrity checks. Pointers on how to do this or something similar would be much appreciated.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You'll want to use ESEUtil. Not much has changed in it over the past 3 Exchange versions.

Here is one guide about how to use ESEUtil to do some basic database checks in Exchange 2010:
[http://msexchangeguru.com/2009/07/12/exchange\-database\-recovery\-using\-eseutil\-commands/](http://msexchangeguru.com/2009/07/12/exchange-database-recovery-using-eseutil-commands/)

For example, to run an integrity check on a database named priv1\.edb located in D:\\Restore, try:

```
ESEUTIL /G "D:\Restore\priv1.edb“

```

ISINTEG is designed especially to check integrity of Exchange stores, but I believe it only works on databases in a running Exchange system. ESEUtil only requires the database files.

53.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An IT administrator wants to verify the integrity of Exchange 2010 database backups without performing a full restore. Which of the following approaches is most appropriate and efficient for this task?

A) Use ISINTEG to perform integrity checks on the backed-up database files
B) Restore the entire Exchange environment on a separate server to test the backups
C) Use ESEUtil with the /G parameter to run an integrity check on the database file
D) Export the database to a PST file and attempt to open it in Outlook

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
A) Incorrect. ISINTEG is designed for checking integrity of Exchange stores, but it typically works only on databases in a running Exchange system, not on backup files.

B) Incorrect. While this would be a thorough test, it's not efficient and requires significant hardware resources, which the administrator stated they don't have.

C) Correct. ESEUtil is the appropriate tool for checking Exchange database integrity without requiring a full Exchange environment. The /G parameter specifically performs an integrity check on the database file, and ESEUtil can work directly with the backup files.

D) Incorrect. Exporting to PST and opening in Outlook wouldn't provide a comprehensive integrity check of the database and wouldn't be practical for large databases.

The correct approach, as mentioned in the documentation, is to use ESEUtil with the /G parameter. This allows for integrity checking of the backed-up database files without needing to restore the entire Exchange environment.

\#\#\# User: I am not able to understand the difference between the joint density function and density function for a random variable $Z \= X\_1 \+ X\_2$, where $X\_1, X\_2$ are uniform random variables in $\[0,1]$.

I think joint density in this case is $f\_{X\_1, X\_2}\\left(x\_1,x\_2\\right) \= 1$ ([reference](http://www.math.wm.edu/%7Eleemis/chart/UDR/PDFs/StandarduniformStandardtriangular.pdf))

Likewise the density function $f\_Z$ is defined as convolution of $f\_{X\_1}$ and $f\_{X\_2}$ ([reference: page 8](http://www.dartmouth.edu/%7Echance/teaching_aids/books_articles/probability_book/Chapter7.pdf))

Could someone please explain the difference between the two?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you don't write down the support, you may not see what's going on \-\- but as soon as you do, it's a lot clearer.

> I am not able to understand the difference between the joint density function and density function for a random variable Z \= x1 \+ x2 where x1, x2 are uniform rvs in \[0,1].

Note that $f\_{X\_1}(x\_1\)\=1$ for $0\<x\_1\<1$ and $0$ elsewhere; similarly for $X\_2$.

The joint density is bivariate \- the density is a surface.

> I think joint density in this case is f(x1,x2\) \= 1

So, assuming independence, the joint density will be: $f(x\_1,x\_2\) \= f\_{X\_1}(x\_1\)\\, f\_{X\_2}(x\_2\)\= 1 \\times 1\=1$ on the unit square and $0$ elsewhere.

[![![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/mgOyv.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/mgOyv.png)

(At least, "bivariate uniform under independence")

> Likewise the density function of z is defined as convolution of x1 and x2

It is the convolution if they're independent, yes.

The *sum* of a pair of quantities is a single quantity \-\- the sum of a pair of random variables is a univariate random variable. 

The density function of the sum of independent variables goes from the sum of the smallest values of each variable to the sum of the largest values of each variable. Consequently the sum of a pair of independent variates each on $(0,1\)$ will lie in the interval $(0\+0,1\+1\)$ (i.e. on $(0,2\)$).

The shape of the density for the sum (as you'll find if you perform the convolution) is symmetric and triangular, though it's also obvious from direct inspection of a picture of the joint density:

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/T8tPM.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/T8tPM.png)

The blue arrows show all the density at a fixed $x\_1\+x\_2$; this is evaluated at each point along the red line. You can see the amount of density at each point increases linearly until the peak at 1, then decreases linearly again.

54.answer:
Here's a multi-part question based on the given information:

Question: Consider two independent uniform random variables X₁ and X₂, each distributed on the interval [0,1], and their sum Z = X₁ + X₂. 

1) What is the support of the joint density function f(x₁,x₂)?
2) What is the support of the density function f_Z(z) for Z?
3) What is the shape of f_Z(z)?
4) If P(Z ≤ 1) = k, what is the value of k?

A) 1) [0,1] x [0,1]  2) [0,2]  3) Triangular  4) 1/2
B) 1) [0,2] x [0,2]  2) [0,1]  3) Uniform  4) 1/4
C) 1) [0,1] x [0,1]  2) [0,2]  3) Triangular  4) 1/4
D) 1) [0,1] x [0,1]  2) [0,2]  3) Normal  4) 1/3

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
1) The support of the joint density function is the unit square [0,1] x [0,1], as X₁ and X₂ are each uniformly distributed on [0,1].
2) The support of Z = X₁ + X₂ is [0,2], as the minimum possible sum is 0+0=0 and the maximum is 1+1=2.
3) The shape of f_Z(z) is triangular, as can be seen from the convolution of two uniform distributions or by visualizing slices of constant sum in the joint distribution.
4) P(Z ≤ 1) represents the area of the triangle from 0 to 1 in f_Z(z), which is 1/4 of the total area under the density function. This can be calculated as (1/2 * 1 * 1) / (1/2 * 2 * 1) = 1/4.

\#\#\# User: I have the ISO of Windows 10 Pro downloaded with the Media Creation Tool. Is it possible to use this ISO to install the Home edition of Windows 10?

If it is possible, are they any extra hoops I need to run through? With Windows 7 and 8, you needed to used the [Ei.cfg removal tool](http://code.kliu.org/misc/winisoutils/). Is this still needed with Windows 10 and does the same tool still work?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It is possible, but you need to put the iso onto a **usb disk.** (4GB or more, I reccomend 8GB just in case)

Now download the [Windows 7 USB/DVD Download Tool](https://wudt.codeplex.com/) and install it, afterwards open it and select the ISO file, click USB then let it do its job.

Once it says its completed, go to Computer (Or this pc) and click your USB.

Then navigate to the sources folder and delete the `ei.cfg` file.

When you load your windows 10 installer from usb, it will show all windows installations!

Question: You want to install Windows 10 Home edition using an ISO of Windows 10 Pro that you downloaded with the Media Creation Tool. Which of the following steps is NOT necessary to achieve this?

B) Navigate to the 'sources' folder on the USB drive and delete the 'ei.cfg' file
C) Use the Ei.cfg removal tool as was required for Windows 7 and 8
D) Ensure you have a USB drive with at least 4GB of storage space

Option A is a necessary step to create a bootable USB drive from the ISO.
Option B is crucial for allowing the installer to show all Windows editions, including Home.
Option D is important to ensure you have sufficient space for the installation files.

The Ei.cfg removal tool is not mentioned as a requirement for Windows 10, making it the unnecessary step in this process.

\#\#\# User: I have some 20\+ year old garage door openers, and one works great, the other will sometimes open/close fine. 

Sometimes when I hit the switch there is a click and a buzz like the motor is trying to lift, but the door does not move. If I hit the switch again it stops. If I go over to the door and pull it up about an inch (or pull it down, if it's open) the motor "catches" and it goes up/down just fine.

Is there a slack adjustment of some sort I can look at, or is the motor bad? I replaced the capacitor on the door that is not working about 6 months ago, and have replaced the springs and safety cables on both doors at about the same time.

Any ideas?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Dry air is more dense than humid air, so your thinking about humid air accumulating near the ceiling makes sense. Because it's a basement, however, I'm going to assume humidity is coming through the floor or walls. Tackling the source of the humidity by letting drier air circulate along the floor and walls will probably be most effective at drying the space.

Your best bet may be to mount the fan as an intake on the bottom grate, so less humid air blows onto the floor and quickly disperses rising moisture. It would also help to open up some air space along the floor. You could achieve this by storing your items on a raised shelf or pallet. Providing this extra space for air circulation might even be enough to keep your storage room sufficiently dry without forced ventilation.

57.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A homeowner is experiencing issues with humidity in their basement storage room. Which of the following solutions would be most effective in addressing the problem?

A) Install a dehumidifier in the center of the room
B) Mount a fan as an exhaust on the upper grate to remove humid air
C) Mount a fan as an intake on the bottom grate to circulate drier air
D) Seal all cracks and openings in the basement walls and floor

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
The correct answer is C - mounting a fan as an intake on the bottom grate to circulate drier air. This solution addresses several key points mentioned in the documentation:

1. It tackles the source of humidity, which is likely coming through the floor or walls in a basement.
2. It allows drier air to circulate along the floor and walls, which is most effective at drying the space.
3. It helps disperse rising moisture quickly.

Option A (installing a dehumidifier) might help, but it doesn't address the circulation issue as effectively.
Option B (exhaust fan on upper grate) would remove air, but not necessarily tackle the source of humidity at floor level.
Option D (sealing cracks) might prevent some moisture, but doesn't address the existing humidity or improve air circulation.

The documentation also suggests raising stored items off the floor to improve air circulation, which supports the idea that addressing the issue from the bottom up is most effective.

\#\#\# User: I work in a company which uses 3 subnets, 10\.0\.0\.0/16, 10\.1\.0\.0/16 and 10\.2\.0\.0/16\. The 3 subnets are connected using layer 3 switches (10\.0\.100\.200, 10\.1\.100\.200, 10\.2\.100\.200\), all of the machines on each subnet use the layer 3 switch as it's default gateway, which then directs the traffic to the real gateway which currently is 10\.1\.0\.2

I have recently configured a new gateway on 10\.0\.0\.1, and have begun testing this new gateway, for my client machines on the 10\.0\.0\.0/16 subnet this is not an issue, I simply changed the default gateway assigned via DHCP to these machines to the new address and the traffic went out through the new gateway instead of going to the layer 3 switch.

I want to test this on another site as well, as we have different teams in each building who need access to different websites, and I want to make sure before we switch everything over that each team can access what they need to do their work.

So on a Windows workstation on the 10\.2\.0\.0/16 network I tried setting the default gateway of the machine to 10\.0\.0\.1, I checked where the traffic went to and it still went out through the old gateway (using tracert to 8\.8\.8\.8 it gets there but through the old gateway, using tracert 10\.0\.0\.1, it reaches 10\.0\.0\.1\). I believe the default gateway setting is being overridden by the static route table on the layer 3 switches.

I'm trying to figure out if it possible to set a static route on the machines in question so they can direct their gateway traffic to 10\.0\.0\.1 and avoid it being overridden by the Layer 3 switches.

I used:

```
route add 0.0.0.0 mask 0.0.0.0 10.0.0.1 if 0x2

```

This was accepted by Windows, but repeating my tracert tests the traffic still goes out through the old gateway. I was hoping I could do:

```
route add 0.0.0.0 mask 0.0.0.0 10.0.0.1 if 0x2
route add 10.0.0.1 mask 0.0.0.0 10.0.100.200 if 0x2
route add 10.0.100.200 mask 0.0.0.0 10.2.100.200 if 0x2

```

But this also failed, running the second and 3rd commands Windows reported:

```
The route addition failed: The specified mask parameter is invalid. (Destination & Mask) != Destination.

```

**So I know the commands I am running won't work, but is it possible to force Windows to direct its traffic through the layer 3 switches to my new gateway or am I on a fruitless search?**

If I need to alter the static routes on the layer 3 switches I don't mind doing this, I have a maintenance window planned on Sunday anyway so I can do some tinkering then. I would rather not do this during working hours, for obvious reasons.

Just to clarify the links between sites, each layer 3 switch has the following connections:

```
gateway     , fibre link 1, fibre link 2
10.0.100.200,             , 192.168.10.1
10.1.100.200, 192.168.20.1, 192.168.10.2
10.2.100.200, 192.168.20.2,

```

So in order for my traffic to get to 10\.0\.0\.1 from 10\.2\.249\.28 (my testing machine) it needs to go through 10\.2\.100\.200 \> 192\.168\.20\.1 \> 192\.168\.10\.1 \> 10\.0\.0\.1

The layer 3 switches in question are Netgear FSM7326P and GSM7328FS.

**If, as I am starting to suspect I cannot do this by setting the static routes within Windows, is it possible to define a static route for individual IP addresses on the layer 3 switches?** Since I am currently testing I only want traffic from the 3 or 4 machines I will configure for testing to go through the new gateway for now, I want all the other traffic to continue to flow as before.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: A default gateway on a system defines which address on its local broadcast domain to send data for addresses which lie outside the directly connected subnets. Since 10\.0\.0\.1 is outside of 10\.2\.0\.0/16, a host on 10\.2\.0\.0 still needs to know which address within 10\.2\.0\.0 to send the packets to in order for it to be forwarded. Once the packet hits the gateway within 10\.2\.0\.0, then it's up to that gateway how to handle it.

Creative static routes based on access control lists may be possible, depending on your networking gear.

In my opinion, your best bet would be to connect the new router/gateway (10\.0\.0\.1\) to the other subnets. Depending on the hardware you are using, you can accomplish this with either additional physical links or a mutually compatible trunking protocol. Once you have your new gateway connected to all three subnets, you will be able to manually connect the other computers to test.

That said, I'm confused as to what exactly you're testing that requires all three of these /16s to be able choose multiple gateways. If you just want to make sure it works, your initial subnet test seems to confirm that.

Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A company uses three subnets (10.0.0.0/16, 10.1.0.0/16, and 10.2.0.0/16) connected by Layer 3 switches. A new gateway (10.0.0.1) has been configured, and the network administrator wants to test routing traffic from a workstation in the 10.2.0.0/16 subnet through this new gateway. Which of the following approaches is most likely to succeed in routing traffic from the 10.2.0.0/16 subnet to the new gateway at 10.0.0.1?

A) Set the default gateway on the workstation to 10.0.0.1 and add a static route in Windows using the command: route add 0.0.0.0 mask 0.0.0.0 10.0.0.1 if 0x2

B) Configure static routes on the Layer 3 switches to direct traffic from specific IP addresses to the new gateway

C) Add multiple static routes on the workstation to define the path through the Layer 3 switches to reach 10.0.0.1

D) Connect the new gateway (10.0.0.1) directly to all three subnets using additional physical links or a compatible trunking protocol

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. Connecting the new gateway (10.0.0.1) directly to all three subnets is the most effective solution. This approach allows the new gateway to be directly reachable from all subnets, bypassing the need for complex routing through the Layer 3 switches. 

Option A would fail because setting the default gateway to an address outside the local subnet (10.2.0.0/16) won't work without proper routing in place. 

Option B could potentially work but would require complex configuration on the Layer 3 switches and may not be scalable. 

Option C would not work because Windows rejected the attempt to add multiple static routes with the given syntax.

Option D provides a direct and manageable solution that allows for easy testing and eventual implementation of the new gateway across all subnets.

59.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: When using v-for to generate form fields for multiple objects in Vue.js, what is the most likely cause of all objects being updated simultaneously instead of independently when a single field is changed?

A) The v-model directive is not being used correctly on the form fields
B) The objects in the array lack unique identifiers
C) The v-for loop is not properly indexed
D) Vue.js is treating all objects in the array as references to the same object

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
The issue described in the question is a common problem in Vue.js when working with arrays of objects. Vue's reactivity system can sometimes treat all objects in an array as references to the same object, causing changes to one object to affect all others. This is especially true if the objects are created dynamically or have similar structures.

A is incorrect because the v-model directive is being used correctly in the provided code snippet.

B is incorrect because the question states that unique identifiers have been created for each object.

C is incorrect because the v-for loop in the provided code is correctly indexed (v-for="(opportunity, index) in opportunities").

D is the correct answer because it accurately describes the behavior observed, where Vue is treating all objects in the array as if they were the same, despite having unique identifiers. This is a known issue in Vue when working with arrays of objects, and often requires special handling or the use of Vue.set() to ensure proper reactivity.
